title: EcoCeres and British Airways Sign SAF Deal to Reduce 400K Tonnes of CO₂
description:
British Airways signed a multi-year agreement with renewable fuel producer EcoCeres to supply sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) to reduce lifecycle carbon by up to 400,000 metric tonnes.
The agreement will assist British Airways in achieving its target of running 10 percent of flights on SAF by 2030, as per the UK government's SAF policy.
British Airways partnership is embraced as a milestone for EcoCeres in securing further worldwide access to the SAF market.
British Airways' overarching business strategy for sustainability is to be 2050 net-zero carbon, and SAF forms the cornerstone for such a strategy.
Source: EcoCeres, British Airways
text:
British Airways signed a multi-year agreement with renewable fuel producer EcoCeres to supply sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) to reduce lifecycle carbon by up to 400,000 metric tonnes. The SAF will be made using used cooking oil only as biomass feedstocks. The agreement will assist British Airways in achieving its target of running 10 percent of flights on SAF by 2030, as per the UK government's SAF policy.

It is made by Hong Kong company EcoCeres and has the potential to cut lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions by as much as 80 percent on average versus traditional fossil-derived jet fuel. Carbon reductions from the deal are forecast at the equivalent of the carbon footprint of a combined total of about 240,000 return economy-class flights between New York and London.

British Airways is part of a network of expanding airlines to try out greener fuel in a bid to reduce the environmentally harmful nature of flying. British Airways' Sustainable Aviation Fuel, for example, covered 2.7 percent of the airline's fuel consumption in 2024 and reduced carbon intensity by 13 percent compared to the 2019 baseline. One advantage of SAF is that its chemistry is the same as conventional fossil jet fuel, and therefore it will be feasible to blend it with current airplane engines and airport refuelling infrastructure without it requiring to be changed.

Although SAF continues to emit carbon dioxide when it burns, its net impact on greenhouse gases is much lower since the carbon is derived from renewable, biological origins and hence stays in the natural carbon cycle. SAF is thereby therefore a key near-to-medium-term solution to aviation de-carbonization, at least until industry is technology mature with hydrogen propulsion and electric flight.

EcoCeres, sponsored by private equity backers Kerogen Capital and Bain Capital, produces low-carbon fuels on commercial scale. A spin-off of Hong Kong towngas utility company and ISCC-certified, its sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), hydrotreated vegetable oil (HVO), and renewable naphtha are all produced on the back of waste and residue feedstocks.

British Airways partnership is embraced as a milestone for EcoCeres in securing further worldwide access to the SAF market. The deal is proof of increasing commercial aviation demand for low-carbon alternative fuel and further endorsement of waste-based biofuels' contribution to worldwide climate ambitions.

While in view is the environmental return, scale availability worldwide is not yet imminent. Global SAF use continues to be below 3 percent of all aviation fuel used worldwide. Industry experts foresee a transition at scale worldwide will depend on increasing production levels, building supply infrastructure, and consistent government incentivization by way of regulation.

The production of SAF is currently limited by feedstock availability, low yields, and the low number of commercial facilities. Indeed, developments like the research work by British Airways and EcoCeres are in the direction of establishing a system for sustainable markets along the way to fulfilling requirements someday across the globe.

Although neither of the carriers reports the size or terms of the deal, the strategic rationale is clear: both of them wish to minimize plane emissions in the race towards world net-zero ambitions. British Airways' overarching business strategy for sustainability is to be 2050 net-zero carbon, and SAF forms the cornerstone for such a strategy.

Sale of alternative fuel to aviation is a sign that the airline sector desires to break free from its carbon past. Pressure on the world airlines sector to cut carbon emissions will grow, and agreements between carriers and manufacturers will be more rapid in pace, giving birth to green aviation.

Source: EcoCeres, British Airways

text:
Kenya Airways Soars to New Heights in 2025, Sweeping Prestigious Awards, Dominating Sustainability, and Shocking the Aviation World with Record-Breaking Success!

(Image Source: KATA Kenya)

In 2025, Kenya Airways cemented its position as a major force in African and global aviation, earning widespread acclaim for its service excellence, sustainability efforts, and financial revival. The national carrier marked an extraordinary year with a series of prestigious awards, operational milestones, and strategic initiatives aimed at strengthening its network and leadership in the aviation industry.

Africa’s Leading Airline and Multiple Accolades

Kenya Airways’ remarkable year began with a triumph at the 32nd Annual World Travel Awards Africa & Indian Ocean Gala Ceremony held in Dar es Salaam. The airline was named Africa’s Leading Airline for 2025, a highly coveted title that recognizes the carrier’s exceptional service, innovation, and operational performance. This award was accompanied by three additional accolades: Africa’s Leading Airline Brand, Africa’s Leading Airline – Business Class, and Africa’s Leading Inflight Magazine (Msafiri).

These four victories underscored Kenya Airways’ commitment to delivering high-quality services across all aspects of the passenger experience, from inflight hospitality to the strength of its brand. The recognition also highlighted the success of Msafiri, the airline’s flagship inflight magazine, which has resonated with passengers by blending cultural storytelling with operational performance.

Sustainable Aviation Fuel Initiative and Environmental Leadership

Kenya Airways made significant strides in its sustainability efforts during 2025. In October, the airline achieved a continental milestone by operating Africa’s first intra-continental flight using a 50 percent Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) blend on its Nairobi–Cape Town route. This initiative was in line with global standards under the International Air Transport Association (IATA) and CORSIA, marking a significant step toward reducing aviation’s environmental impact. The SAF initiative aligns with Kenya Airways’ broader commitment to environmental leadership and sustainability.

These efforts include plans to incorporate SAF blending on European routes, with the airline projecting a reduction of tens of thousands of tonnes of carbon emissions annually. As part of its strategy to lead environmental aviation practices in Africa, Kenya Airways has emerged as a prominent player in the drive for sustainable air travel.

Record Financial Performance and Strategic Partnerships

The carrier’s success extended beyond service awards and sustainability. By December 2025, Kenya Airways achieved its first net profit in 11 years, signaling a robust financial recovery after years of pandemic-related disruptions and challenges. The airline’s ability to turn around its financial performance, despite global industry challenges, highlights its strong leadership and commitment to long-term growth.

Strategic partnerships were key to expanding Kenya Airways’ global reach. The airline deepened its alliance with Qatar Airways, enhancing its codeshare agreement to cover 19 destinations across Africa, Asia, and the Middle East. This partnership not only strengthens Nairobi’s position as a key regional hub but also boosts connectivity for passengers traveling between continents.

Additionally, Kenya Airways’ growth trajectory was supported by its cargo division. In February, Kenya Airways Cargo was named African Air Cargo Airline of the Year at the Air Cargo Africa Conference in Nairobi, further solidifying its role in regional logistics and trade facilitation.

Kenya Airways Leads in Workforce Development

Internal growth and employee engagement played a pivotal role in the airline’s success in 2025. Earlier in the year, the airline was awarded Top Employer of the Year by The Employers Institute. This recognition reflects Kenya Airways’ ongoing efforts to improve its organizational culture, enhance employee satisfaction, and develop its workforce, all of which are critical elements in the carrier’s turnaround strategy.

Recognition at National and Regional Levels

Kenya Airways’ accolades were not limited to international events. At the Kenya Travel Industry Business Awards (KeTIBA) in December, the airline secured two major honors: Best Regional Airline and Best International Airline. These awards were voted on by industry professionals and travelers, reinforcing Kenya Airways’ dual role as a key regional connector and global aviation player.

Leadership Change and Strategic Direction for 2026

As Kenya Airways looked toward the future, it also experienced a shift in leadership. Captain George Kamal was appointed Acting Group Managing Director and CEO, signaling a new phase for the airline as it consolidates its gains and seeks further operational improvements. Under his leadership, Kenya Airways is poised to continue its upward trajectory, focusing on enhanced efficiency, strategic partnerships, and market competitiveness in the years to come.

A Bright Future for Kenya Airways

With a combination of continental awards, environmental initiatives, strategic alliances, and financial success, Kenya Airways has set the stage for continued growth in 2026. The airline’s focus on sustainable practices, customer experience, and expanding its global footprint positions it as one of Africa’s leading carriers with a growing presence on the world aviation stage. As it enters 2026, Kenya Airways is well-equipped to maintain its momentum and enhance its role as a key player in African and global air travel.

(With insights from Kenya Association Of Travel Agents)

title: Rise of smart terminal: Inside the human-light revolution of 2026 - STAT Times
authors: Divya Shah, The STAT Trade Times
description:
The global air cargo sector is currently undergoing a profound metamorphosis.
According to Airbus’ 2025 Cargo Global Market Forecast (GMF), the global skyline is projected to become considerably more crowded.
The air cargo terminal of the 2026–2030 period is resolving this through a radical transition toward smart terminals.
Forward-thinking cargo hubs like LGG are proactively addressing the future gap in cargo aviation infrastructure by focusing on three key areas.
The air cargo industry of 2026 is no longer a supporting actor in global trade; it is the lead architect.
text:
The global air cargo sector is currently undergoing a profound metamorphosis. Once characterised as a labor-intensive, documentation-heavy foundation of international commerce, the industry is rapidly divesting itself of its analog processes. In their stead, a highly interconnected, data-centric, and increasingly automated ecosystem is emerging, one that is redefining the movement of goods globally in an era of instant gratification and environmental urgency.

Driven by a staggering $8.1 trillion e-commerce boom and an industry-wide mandate for net-zero emissions, the aviation cargo landscape of 2026 transcends the mere physical movement of boxes. It has become a digital-first frontier where success is predicated not solely on fleet size, but on the capacity to optimally orchestrate the data those aircraft generate.

According to Airbus’ 2025 Cargo Global Market Forecast (GMF), the global skyline is projected to become considerably more crowded. The report anticipates that the worldwide dedicated freighter fleet will surge to 3,420 aircraft over the next two decades, representing a substantial 45% increase from current levels.

This influx of capacity does not signify a simple replication of existing assets. The GMF outlines a strategy of renewal and specialised growth. To satisfy the projected demand for cargo aviation, a total of 2,605 additional freighters will be necessitated between 2026 and 2030, according to the Airbus GMF.

This requirement is segmented into three primary categories: 1,120 small aircraft, which will be essential for maintaining regional agility; 855 mid-size widebodies; and 630 large widebodies, which are requisite for transcontinental heavy lifting operations.

Perhaps most indicative of the industry’s pivot toward circularity and efficiency is the origin of these aircraft. While 935 will be new constructions, the vast majority 1,670 aircraft will be passenger-to-freighter (P2F) conversions. This trend injects new operational life into existing airframes, enabling airlines to strategically redeploy assets into the high-margin cargo sector as passenger travel patterns stabilise.

While aircraft technology advances significantly, the industry has long identified a persistent bottleneck: the warehouse. This terrestrial hurdle has historically slowed transit, encumbered by manual sorting and paper manifests.

The air cargo terminal of the 2026–2030 period is resolving this through a radical transition toward smart terminals. These facilities are intentionally designed to be human-light, prioritising extreme throughput speed and the near-total elimination of processing errors.

"We perceive the evolution toward more automated, human-light cargo terminals not as a binary choice between efficiency and survival, but as a strategic imperative," stated Frédéric Brun, Head of Commercial Cargo & Logistics at Liege Airport (LGG) and Torsten Wefers, Vice President Sales & Marketing at LGG.

At CargoLand by LGG, the practical implementation of this vision is evident. By deploying AI-powered vision systems and autonomous mobile robots (AMRs), terminals are reporting a 70% reduction in errors. These robots execute palletisation and sorting with a level of precision that human crews are unable to replicate consistently over a 24-hour shift.

Brun noted that this initiative is not focused on replacing personnel, but on empowering them. By utilising tools such as digital twins, virtual replicas of the physical warehouse, operators can simulate workflows in real-time, proactively identifying potential bottlenecks before they manifest on the floor.

The infrastructure of tomorrow

The evolution extends beyond the confines of the warehouse and into the fundamental fuel and flight paths of the industry. The middle-mile drone has formally transitioned from a nascent technology to a logistical imperative.

New-generation cargo drones, developed by companies such as Dronamics (Bulgaria/UK), Elroy Air, and Sabrewing Aircraft Company, have moved beyond carrying light parcels. These autonomous aerial vehicles are now capable of transporting 200–500kg across hundreds of miles.

Aviation confronts a formidable path toward achieving Net Zero. Innovation in propulsion is bifurcating into solutions for short-haul (Electric/Hydrogen) and long-haul.

“Alternative propulsion for regional middle-mile cargo, specifically electric vertical take-off and landing (eVTOL) and hydrogen-propulsion aircraft, are progressing rapidly from prototype stages to certification,” said Brun.

According to IATA reports, Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) is projected to constitute less than 1% of total fuel consumption in 2026, a reflection of the inefficacy of the current policy environment.

This deficiency is further compounded by the lack of harmonisation between CORSIA (Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation) and various regional initiatives, which engenders fragmentation and curtails substantive emissions reductions.

Forward-thinking cargo hubs like LGG are proactively addressing the future gap in cargo aviation infrastructure by focusing on three key areas. Firstly, they are committing to complete electrification, transitioning all ground equipment to 100% electric operations.

Secondly, they are ensuring the immediate availability of SAF through the development of dedicated fuel infrastructure. Finally, these hubs are implementing cargo connect, a comprehensive digital ecosystem designed to facilitate the seamless sharing of critical data among airlines, handlers, and all logistics partners.

The brain of the operation

As the physical and digital infrastructure attains maturity, the commercial dimension of the business is also undergoing a revolution. For decades, the industry operated in silos, with sales (GSAs), operations, and tech infrequently communicating effectively.

Aerion, a commercial holding company, is challenging the current fragmented model of cargo aviation. It unites ECS Group, Global GSA Group, CargoTech, Healthc’Air, Mail & More, TCE, and Squair. Founded by the leaders of the ECS Group, Aerion signifies an evolution from simple airline representation toward full operational orchestration.

“For nearly three decades, we have been actively shaping the air cargo industry rather than simply adapting to it,” said Adrien Thominet, Founder and Chairman of Aerion. “First by establishing ECS Group, then by integrating Global GSA Group, we constructed an unparalleled network. Aerion is the mechanism that connects these components.”

Aerion centralises strategic intelligence by consolidating a range of specialised entities, each focusing on a distinct area of cargo aviation: CargoTech provides high-end digital capabilities for planning and optimisation; TCE offers expertise in safety, security, and quality operations; Squair delivers specialised back-office and claims support; Mail&More handles the high-velocity requirements of e-commerce and postal flows; and Healthc'Air manages the rigorous requirements of temperature-sensitive medical logistics.

In practice, Aerion functions as a strategic central intelligence unit. While each entity preserves its operational independence, they function under a consolidated commercial strategy aimed at achieving measurable, sustainable profit.

Perhaps the most significant paradigm shift highlighted by the emergence of Aerion is the industry's new relationship with data. Historically, possessing information conferred a competitive advantage. Today, data is ubiquitous; it has become a commodity.

The true disruption in 2026 resides not in access to data, but in the capability to exploit it judiciously. Industry standards such as IATA’s ONE Record have provided the requisite foundation for a cleaner, consistent methodology for information sharing. However, Aerion contends that this foundation merely represents the beginning.

"The substantive difference is no longer determined by ‘who possesses the data, but ‘who truly understands how to leverage it to drive profitability," the company added.

Aerion does not seek ownership of the data, but rather the orchestration of its utilisation, translating market signals into precise decisions concerning network planning, pricing, and customer segmentation. In this environment, technology serves as a decision accelerator.

The rise of the neutral hub

As the industry advances, the concept of the neutral hub is becoming increasingly appealing to traditional carriers. To maintain relevance in the face of tech-heavy integrators and agile startups, traditional airlines require operating environments that offer 24/7 flexibility unconstrained by passenger-driven schedules.

Torsten Wefers, Vice President of Sales & Marketing at LGG, observes that the objective is to ensure a seamless integration between air and ground logistics. By utilising hubs such as CargoLand, airlines can operate within an ecosystem where pricing, legal compliance, safety protocols, and sales execution are comprehensively aligned.

The air cargo industry of 2026 is no longer a supporting actor in global trade; it is the lead architect. By blending physical capacity with digital orchestration, the sector is finally moving at the speed of the modern world.

text:
Kenya Airways has capped 2025 as one of the most successful years in its recent history, sweeping major continental awards, recording strategic operational milestones, and closing the year with high-profile national recognition that underscores its renewed strength in African and global aviation.

In July, at the 32nd Annual World Travel Awards Africa & Indian Ocean Gala Ceremony held in Dar es Salaam, the national carrier was crowned Africa’s Leading Airline, while also clinching three additional top honours — Africa’s Leading Airline Brand, Africa’s Leading Airline – Business Class, and Africa’s Leading Inflight Magazine (Msafiri). The clean sweep of four prestigious titles reaffirmed Kenya Airways’ leadership in service excellence, brand strength, and passenger experience.

The accolades reflected a year in which the airline not only strengthened customer confidence but also advanced its strategic priorities, focusing on connectivity, sustainability, and service innovation.

Awards Underscore Operational Excellence

Winning Africa’s Leading Airline 2025 — the most coveted title in the regional aviation sector — signaled strong validation from industry peers and travellers alike. Recognition of Msafiri, the airline’s flagship inflight magazine, further highlighted Kenya Airways’ ability to combine operational performance with cultural storytelling and brand engagement.

Earlier in the year, the airline was also named Top Employer of the Year 2025 by The Employers Institute, pointing to internal progress in workforce development, employee engagement, and organizational culture — a critical pillar in the carrier’s turnaround strategy.

Sustainability and Innovation Take Flight

In October, Kenya Airways marked a continental first by operating Africa’s first intra-continental flight using 50 percent Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) attributes on its Nairobi–Cape Town route. The milestone aligned with global emissions reduction standards under the International Air Transport Association (IATA) and CORSIA, reinforcing the airline’s commitment to climate-conscious aviation.

The SAF initiative forms part of broader sustainability efforts, including SAF blending on European routes, projected to reduce tens of thousands of tonnes of carbon emissions annually and position Kenya Airways among Africa’s environmental aviation leaders.

Connectivity and Strategic Partnerships

On the network front, 2025 saw the airline deepen strategic partnerships to expand its global reach. Kenya Airways strengthened its codeshare agreement with Qatar Airways, extending coverage to 19 destinations across Africa, Asia, and the Middle East and enhancing seamless connectivity through Nairobi and Doha.

Aviation analysts say these partnerships are central to reinforcing Jomo Kenyatta International Airport’s role as a regional hub, supporting both inbound tourism and intra-African business travel.

Financial Turnaround and Leadership Transition

Industry insiders describe 2025 as a pivotal transition year for the national carrier. By December, Kenya Airways had reportedly recorded its first net profit in 11 years, marking a dramatic turnaround after prolonged pandemic-related disruptions and structural financial challenges.

The year also brought leadership changes, with Captain George Kamal appointed Acting Group Managing Director and CEO, signaling a new phase focused on consolidating gains, improving efficiency, and navigating an increasingly competitive aviation environment.

Cargo Growth and Broader Aviation Impact

Kenya Airways’ momentum extended beyond passenger operations. In February, Kenya Airways Cargo was named African Air Cargo Airline of the Year at the Air Cargo Africa Conference in Nairobi, underscoring the airline’s growing role in regional logistics, trade facilitation, and supply chain resilience across East and Central Africa.

December KeTIBA Wins Seal the Year

The airline closed 2025 on a high note in December, winning two major honours at the Kenya Travel Industry Business Awards (KeTIBA) — Best Regional Airline and Best International Airline. The dual recognition, voted on by industry professionals and travelers, cemented Kenya Airways’ position as both a continental connector and a global competitor.

Looking Ahead

Despite ongoing challenges facing African aviation — including cost volatility, infrastructure pressures, and intense competition — Kenya Airways’ performance in 2025 signals a carrier emerging from turbulence with renewed momentum.

As it enters 2026, Kenya Airways’ blend of continental awards, sustainability leadership, expanding partnerships, financial recovery, and national recognition paints the picture of an airline not just reclaiming regional prominence but strengthening its place on the global aviation stage.

text:
The global Refined Petroleum Products Market remains a foundational pillar of the world’s energy ecosystem, powering transportation, industry, and myriad commercial activities across continents. Refined petroleum products — including gasoline, diesel, jet fuel, kerosene, and other distillates — are vital to economic growth, even as the broader energy transition unfolds. Demand patterns are shaped by mobility trends, industrial activity, and evolving consumer preferences. Ongoing investments in refinery capacity expansion, integration with petrochemical complexes, and emission reduction technologies are steering market dynamics. In this comprehensive overview, we explore the key market driver, recent technology advancements, and crucial regional insights that define the market’s trajectory and opportunities ahead.

Market Driver

At the heart of the refined petroleum products market’s expansion lies the surging demand for transportation fuels. Rapid urbanization and rising vehicle ownership in emerging economies continue to drive gasoline and diesel consumption. Road transport remains the largest segment, accounting for a substantial share of fuel demand due to the vast number of passenger cars, commercial trucks, buses, and two‑wheelers navigating expanding transport networks. Diesel, in particular, is essential not just for freight and logistics but also for agricultural and construction machinery, amplifying its market importance.

Simultaneously, the recovery and growth of commercial aviation are bolstering demand for jet fuel. With air travel rebounding from pandemic‑era lows, airlines are increasing flights and fleet utilization, thereby lifting refined product consumption. Industrial sectors, ranging from manufacturing to mining and energy generation, further add to diesel and heavy fuel oil requirements, embedding refined products deeply into economic infrastructure.

Amidst this robust demand, refineries are also responding to environmental mandates and fuel quality standards. Stricter regulations — such as low‑sulfur fuel requirements and emissions caps — are prompting upgrades to existing facilities and incentivizing the production of cleaner fuel variants. These regulatory pressures act as both challenges and drivers, as producers invest in refining processes that can deliver compliant, high‑value products. The outcome is a market that not only grows in volume but increasingly emphasizes fuel quality, environmental performance, and operational flexibility.

Technology Advancement

Technological innovation is a powerful catalyst transforming how refined petroleum products are produced, optimized, and delivered. Modern refineries are adopting advanced processing technologies such as hydrocracking, catalytic reforming, and deep desulfurization — all aimed at boosting yields, improving fuel purity, and meeting stringent environmental standards. These technologies allow producers to convert heavier crude fractions into lighter, higher‑value products like gasoline and diesel more efficiently.

Digital transformation plays a pivotal role in operational excellence. The integration of real‑time data analytics, artificial intelligence (AI), and the Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) enables predictive maintenance, optimized process control, and energy efficiency enhancements. For example, AI‑driven models can forecast equipment failures before they occur, minimizing downtime and extending the life of critical units. Digital twins — virtual replicas of physical refinery operations — help engineers simulate process changes, explore optimization scenarios, and enhance safety margins.

Refineries are also exploring cleaner fuel technologies and alternative feedstocks as part of sustainability strategies. This includes co‑processing bio‑based feedstocks such as vegetable oils or waste fats alongside conventional crude, producing biodiesel blends and lower‑carbon fuel alternatives. The development of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) and renewable diesel is particularly notable, reflecting the industry’s efforts to reduce lifecycle emissions from transportation fuels.

Innovation in catalyst development is another key area. New catalyst formulations enhance reaction efficiency in fluid catalytic cracking (FCC) and hydroprocessing units, leading to improved product yields and reduced environmental impact. Similarly, advancements like modular hydrocrackers offer flexibility in refinery configurations, helping operators adjust quickly to market demands or regulatory changes.

Together, these advancements are not only improving refinery performance but are also helping the market evolve in line with global energy and environmental goals.

Regional Insights

Asia‑Pacific Dominance

The Asia‑Pacific region stands out as the most influential and rapidly expanding market for refined petroleum products. Fueled by industrial growth, rising incomes, expanding transport networks, and significant urbanization, countries like China and India are at the forefront. China continues to lead in refining capacity and consumption, leveraging large domestic markets and export potential. India’s refining expansion — particularly through mega‑projects such as those in Jamnagar and Paradip — underscores the region’s ability to meet both internal demand and global export needs.

Southeast Asian nations are also investing in refinery upgrades to serve growing mobility and industrial sectors. The acceleration in vehicle ownership, stronger logistics networks, and aviation growth are collectively elevating fuel demand across this region.

North America and Europe

In North America, especially the United States, robust infrastructure, high industrial activity, and substantial transportation fuel needs maintain a strong market presence. Investments are geared toward cleaner fuel production and capacity enhancements, even as alternative energy sources and electric vehicle adoption pose long‑term demand challenges.

Europe is navigating a balancing act between energy demand and ambitious environmental targets. While traditional fuel usage persists, the focus on low‑sulfur marine fuels, renewable fuel blends, and carbon reduction technologies is reshaping how refineries operate. Countries are upgrading facilities and embracing hybrid energy solutions to remain competitive while complying with stringent emissions standards.

Middle East & Africa

The Middle East and Africa are unique in their role as both producers and consumers of refined petroleum products. Oil‑rich Gulf nations continue to expand refining and petrochemical complexes, leveraging low‑cost feedstock availability while catering to export markets. Africa, with evolving energy needs and ongoing infrastructure development, presents growth opportunities as new facilities come online and existing ones modernize.

Latin America

title: L'avion électrique sera-t-il un jour accessible au grand public? - 18/01/2026 à 08:30 - Conso
description:
Pour y répondre, les constructeurs aéronautiques misent notamment sur l'avion électrique, une technologie encore en développement mais porteuse de fortes promesses.
La Suède développe le plus grand avion électrique au monde L'annonce de SAS peut paraître prématurée.
En réduisant la capacité à 25 passagers, l'avion peut atteindre 800km d'autonomie.
L'entreprise vise une certification à l'horizon 2028-2030 La start-up allemande Vaeridion développe un avion électrique d'une autonomie de 500km.
Dans sa version finale, il pourrait parcourir jusqu'à 1.000 kilomètres.
text:
Responsable d'environ 3% des émissions mondiales de CO₂, le transport aérien fait face à un défi majeur de décarbonation. Pour y répondre, les constructeurs aéronautiques misent notamment sur l'avion électrique, une technologie encore en développement mais porteuse de fortes promesses. Moins polluant et potentiellement moins coûteux à exploiter, ce nouveau modèle pourrait aussi rebattre les cartes du prix des billets Une bonne nouvelle pour le portefeuille des voyageurs?

La compagnie scandinave SAS prévoit le premier vol en avion électrique pour 2028

En juin 2023, la compagnie aérienne SAS a ouvert les réservations pour ses trois premiers vols commerciaux en avion électrique à destination de la Suède, la Norvège et le Danemark. 90 billets (30 par vol) ont été mis en vente. Ils ont rapidement trouvé preneur. Les heureux élus devront prendre leur mal en patience, ces vols inauguraux n'étant pas prévus avant 2028! Le prix du billet était fixé à 1.946 couronnes suédoises, danoises ou norvégiennes, frais et taxes inclus. Cela correspondait, à cette période, à un tarif de 165 euros pour les passagers suédois, 171 euros pour les Norvégiens, et 261 euros pour les voyageurs danois. Le montant de 1.946 couronnes est un clin d'œil à l'année de création de la compagnie aérienne. Celle-ci espère écrire «un nouveau chapitre de l'histoire de l'aviation».

La Suède développe le plus grand avion électrique au monde

L'annonce de SAS peut paraître prématurée. En 2019, la compagnie a conclu un accord avec Heart Aerospace pour développer des avions électriques. L'entreprise basée près de Göteborg, en Suède, travaille actuellement sur le futur ES-30. Cet appareil d'une envergure de 32 mètres, pouvant embarquer jusqu'à 30 passagers, sera propulsé par quatre moteurs électriques alimentés par des batteries rechargeables en 30 minutes. Il disposera d'une autonomie de 200km, et pourra effectuer un trajet total de 400km grâce à un moteur hybride alimenté en carburant d'aviation durable (CAD, en anglais SAF pour sustainable aviation fuel). En réduisant la capacité à 25 passagers, l'avion peut atteindre 800km d'autonomie.

Le prototype Heart Experimental 1 (Heart X1) devait effectuer son vol-test inaugural au départ de l'aéroport de Plattsburgh, dans l'État de New York, en 2025, mais il a été reporté à deux reprises. Il est désormais prévu pour 2026. Heart Aerospace présentera ensuite un prototype de préproduction, le Heart X2, capable d'effectuer un vol hybride-électrique. L'entreprise vise une certification de l'ES-30 et son exploitation commerciale dès 2028, mais cette date pourrait être décalée.

Plusieurs prototypes pourraient voler d'ici 2030

La start-up américaine BETA Technologies a conçu le Alia CTOL CX300. En septembre 2025, l'avion a effectué un premier vol-test de fret en conditions réelles entre les aéroports de Stavanger et de Bergen, dans le sud-ouest de la Norvège. L'appareil a parcouru les 160km en 55 minutes. Il peut transporter jusqu'à 5 passagers, et dispose d'une autonomie de 400km. L'entreprise vise une certification à l'horizon 2028-2030

La start-up allemande Vaeridion développe un avion électrique d'une autonomie de 500km. Selon Eurocontrol, près d'un tiers des vols au sein de l'Union européenne en 2022 concernaient des distances inférieures ou égales à ce rayon d'action. Cela permet par exemple de couvrir des liaisons comme Londres-Amsterdam, Berlin-Munich ou Madrid-Lisbonne. Vaeridion prévoit le premier vol d'un prototype en 2027, avec une exploitation commerciale dès 2030. L'entreprise vise une clientèle d'affaires aisée, avec des prix de sièges entre 150 et 300 euros

Le concept E9X, créé par la start-up néerlandaise Elysian en collaboration avec l'Université de technologie de Delft, est un avion à réaction entièrement électrique pouvant accueillir jusqu'à 90 passagers, et voler sur 800km. Dans sa version finale, il pourrait parcourir jusqu'à 1.000 kilomètres. Selon l'entreprise, l'appareil serait adapté pour couvrir environ la moitié des vols commerciaux réguliers. Un prototype pourrait voler en 2033. Il reste à savoir si un tel projet est viable sur le plan économique.

L'avion est jusqu'à 26 fois moins cher que le train en Europe

L'ONG Greenpeace a analysé 142 trajets de moins de 1.500 km en Europe, dont 109 transfrontaliers. En pondérant par le nombre de passagers aériens, le train coûte en moyenne 2,5 fois plus cher que l'avion pour voyager en Europe. Certains vols low cost sont jusqu'à 26 fois moins chers que le même trajet en train. L'étude prend l'exemple d'un voyage Barcelone-Londres à 14,99 euros en avion contre 389 euros en train pour une réservation anticipée à moyen terme. Un vol Marseille-Londres est affiché à 15 euros , contre 188 euros pour le rail. En France, 95% des voyages transfrontaliers sont moins chers en avion.

text:
tirto.id - Pabrikan pesawat ATR asal Toulouse, Prancis, menyampaikan pernyataan resmi terkait insiden kecelakaan pesawat jenis ATR 42-500 milik Indonesia Air Transport. Adapun pesawat itu membawa 10 orang yang terdiri dari tujuh kru dan tiga penumpang, kemudian hilang kontak di Maros, Sulawesi Selatan saat dalam penerbangan Yogyakarta-Makassar, Sabtu (17/1/2026).

Dalam keterangannya, ATR menyatakan telah menerima informasi mengenai kecelakaan tersebut dan menyampaikan keprihatinan mendalam kepada seluruh pihak yang terdampak.

“ATR telah diinformasikan bahwa sebuah kecelakaan terjadi di Indonesia yang melibatkan pesawat ATR 42-500. Pikiran pertama kami tertuju kepada seluruh individu yang terdampak oleh kecelakaan ini,” demikian pernyataan resmi ATR melalui situs resminya, dikutip Minggu (18/1/2026).

Hingga saat ini, proses investigasi atas insiden pesawat di Indonesia tersebut masih terus berlangsung di bawah kewenangan otoritas setempat. ATR menyatakan komitmennya untuk bekerja sama secara penuh dan transparan dalam mendukung upaya pengungkapan penyebab kecelakaan.

“Para spesialis ATR sepenuhnya terlibat untuk mendukung investigasi yang dipimpin oleh otoritas Indonesia dan operator,” tulisnya.

Dukungan tersebut mencakup aspek teknis dan keahlian yang dibutuhkan guna membantu mengungkap penyebab insiden secara menyeluruh.

Sebagai informasi, ATR merupakan produsen pesawat regional terbesar di dunia untuk segmen di bawah 90 kursi melalui seri ATR 42 dan ATR 72. Pesawat-pesawat buatan ATR saat ini dioperasikan oleh sekitar 200 maskapai di lebih dari 100 negara, dan rata-rata membuka sekitar 120 rute baru setiap tahunnya, termasuk ke wilayah-wilayah terpencil.

ATR juga dikenal sebagai produsen yang menekankan efisiensi dan keberlanjutan. Pesawat turboprop ATR diklaim menghasilkan emisi karbon hingga 45 persen lebih rendah dibandingkan pesawat jet regional dengan ukuran serupa. Pada Januari 2022, ATR mencatatkan tonggak sejarah dengan menerbangkan pesawat komersial pertama di dunia yang menggunakan 100 persen Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) pada kedua mesinnya.

Sebelumnya, Kementerian Kelautan dan Perikanan (KKP) menjabarkan bahwa Pesawat ATR 42-500 dengan rute Yogyakarta-Makassar yang dilaporkan hilang kontak di wilayah antara Kabupaten Maros dan Kabupaten Pangkep, Sulawesi Selatan, mengangkut total 10 orang.

Menteri Kelautan dan Perikanan, Sakti Wahyu Trenggono, membenarkan tiga penumpang yang berada di pesawat tersebut adalah pegawai KKP.

“Kami sampaikan bahwa benar terdapat pegawai KKP dalam pesawat tersebut yang melakukan misi pengawasan sumber daya kelautan dan perikanan melalui udara atau air surveillance di wilayah pengelolaan perikanan negara Republik Indonesia,” kata Sakti dalam Konferensi Pers KKP, Sabtu (17/1/2026).

Tiga penumpang tersebut adalah Ferry Irawan dengan pangkat Penata Muda Tingkat I dengan jabatan Analis Kapal Pengawas; Deden Mulyana dengan pangkat Penata Muda Tingkat I, jabatannya Pengelola Barang Milik Negara; dan Yoga Naufal jabatannya Operator Foto Udara.

title: Aerial video reveals concerning trend among billionaires in coastal city - The Cool Down
description:
"Look at all of the private jets at Nice airport on takeoff," wrote the original poster.
Worse still, private jet travel is on the rise.
Between 2019 and 2023, private jet pollution went up 50%.
A big part of this increase are empty legs, where private jets fly without passengers on board.
Private jet pollution has immediate effects on local air quality, but the issue is even bigger than that.
text:
An air passenger got quite the view when taking off from France and shared a video clip to the community at r/aviation.

"Look at all of the private jets at Nice airport on takeoff," wrote the original poster.

The French city of Nice has been well aware of the impact of luxury travel on its infrastructure. The city's mayor has previously worked to ban cruise ships from docking there.

Besides being a tacky display of wealth, luxury travel produces an outsized share of pollution. Per passenger emissions from private jets are far higher than commercial airlines. For example, one study suggested that Jeff Bezos' two private jets crank out more pollution in a year than the average Amazon worker could in 207 years.

Worse still, private jet travel is on the rise. Between 2019 and 2023, private jet pollution went up 50%. A big part of this increase are empty legs, where private jets fly without passengers on board.

Private jet pollution has immediate effects on local air quality, but the issue is even bigger than that. Atmospheric pollution traps heat, exacerbates destructive weather patterns, and passes the costs of natural disasters to society at large. This has led to crises in home insurance and agriculture.

The use of sustainable aviation fuel has the potential to reduce pollution from air travel, but there are much lower-impact options available, like rail. Taking the train when possible is not only better for the environment, it can be a very comfortable ride, too.

Reddit commenters were less than pleased to see so many private jets parked in the south of France.

"There are days when we were not able to stay overnight, because the whole apron was occupied," said one community member.

"But my gas car is the problem," replied another.

title: Wings India 2026 set to elevate India as a global aviation hub from Jan 28–31 in Hyderabad
description:
Wings India 2026, Asia’s largest civil aviation event, is set to take off at Begumpet Airport, Hyderabad, from January 28 to 31 , with a grand inaugural ceremony led by Union Minister of Civil Aviation Rammohan Naidu .
The four-day global aviation gathering will bring together policymakers, industry leaders, innovators, investors, and young professionals from across the world.
Their presence will strengthen policy alignment, business collaboration, investment opportunities, and technology transfer, reinforcing India’s role as a trusted global aviation partner.
Wings India 2026 will also feature spectacular flying displays and aerobatic shows , including performances by the Indian Air Force’s Surya Kiran Aerobatic Team , along with static aircraft displays.
An Aviation Job Fair will connect industry leaders with skilled talent, while a Civil Aviation Innovation Challenge for students will promote problem-solving, creativity, and exposure to real-world industry challenges.
text:
Wings India 2026, Asia’s largest civil aviation event, is set to take off at Begumpet Airport, Hyderabad, from January 28 to 31 , with a grand inaugural ceremony led by Union Minister of Civil Aviation Rammohan Naidu . The four-day global aviation gathering will bring together policymakers, industry leaders, innovators, investors, and young professionals from across the world.

Anchored around the theme “Indian Aviation: Paving the Future – From Design to Deployment, Manufacturing to Maintenance, Inclusivity to Innovation and Safety to Sustainability,” Wings India 2026 will showcase India’s rapidly growing aviation sector and its ambitions to become a major hub for manufacturing, services, innovation, and sustainable aviation solutions.

The event will feature an expansive international exhibition , static aircraft displays, flying and aerobatic shows, a high-level global conference, CEO roundtables, B2B and B2G meetings, an aviation job fair, an awards ceremony, and vibrant cultural programmes. Stakeholders from across the aviation value chain including airlines, aircraft and engine manufacturers, MROs, OEMs, technology providers, airport developers, and training institutions will converge to deliberate on emerging trends, investment opportunities, and collaborative pathways shaping the future of civil aviation.

The international conference will include 13 thematic sessions and a Ministerial Plenary, focusing on key areas such as airports, aircraft leasing, helicopters, airlines, air cargo, business aviation, small aircraft, aircraft component manufacturing, sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), flying training and skilling, advanced air mobility (AAM), drones, and women in aviation. These focus areas address sustainability, technological innovation, connectivity, and inclusivity cornerstones for the long-term growth of the aviation sector.

International and domestic participation will be a highlight, with ministerial-level delegations and senior officials from over 20 countries. Their presence will strengthen policy alignment, business collaboration, investment opportunities, and technology transfer, reinforcing India’s role as a trusted global aviation partner. Active participation from Indian states will showcase aviation-led growth, infrastructure development, and investment prospects across the country.

Wings India 2026 will also feature spectacular flying displays and aerobatic shows , including performances by the Indian Air Force’s Surya Kiran Aerobatic Team , along with static aircraft displays. Platforms for exhibitions, chalets, and B2B/B2G meetings will facilitate business partnerships and investment discussions. An Aviation Job Fair will connect industry leaders with skilled talent, while a Civil Aviation Innovation Challenge for students will promote problem-solving, creativity, and exposure to real-world industry challenges.

Cultural programmes reflecting India’s rich heritage will provide delegates and visitors with a unique experiential dimension, while a prestigious awards ceremony will recognise excellence and outstanding contributions to the sector.

title: Air France-KLM Flying Blue Credit Card Changes Make Status Easier To Earn
description:
The Air France-KLM Flying Blue program has a credit card in the United States, issued by Bank of America.
It’s a card that I have, as someone who has Flying Blue Platinum status.
What’s changing about the Air France-KLM credit card Over the coming weeks, we’re going to see some major changes to Flying Blue’s credit card in the United States.
I find the Air France-KLM Flying Blue program to be super useful, which is why I have Platinum status in the program.
The folks at Flying Blue are savvy and understand the US market really well, so you’d think they’d embrace credit card spending as much as possible.
text:
The Air France-KLM Flying Blue program has a credit card in the United States, issued by Bank of America. It’s a card that I have, as someone who has Flying Blue Platinum status. We’ve just learned about some changes coming to the card, and they’re entirely positive, as I see it (thanks to Levi for flagging this).

What’s changing about the Air France-KLM credit card

Over the coming weeks, we’re going to see some major changes to Flying Blue’s credit card in the United States.

For one, in March 2026 we’re going to see the card converted from a Mastercard to a Visa — specifically, it’ll go from being the Air France KLM World Elite Mastercard to being the Air France KLM Visa Signature Card. The transition should be seamless, so existing cardmembers should automatically receive a new version of the card, with a new card number.

More immediately, for applications as of Wednesday, January 21, 2026 (and for existing cardmembers), we’re seeing some improvements to the benefits of the card. It’ll maintain the same $89 annual fee it currently has, with a couple of major changes.

First, we’ll see the card get a new bonus category of earning 3x miles on dining. This complements the existing rewards structure of 3x miles on Air France, KLM, and SkyTeam bookings, plus 1.5x miles on all other everyday spending.

On top of that, we’ll see new anniversary rewards on the card. As before, the card will offer 5,000 anniversary bonus miles after $50 in annual purchases, in addition to 20XPs each card anniversary just for having the card. With these updates, you’ll also be able to earn 80 XPs for annual purchases of at least $15,000, and an enhanced offer of an additional 60 XPs for annual purchases of at least $25,000.

In other words, in total cardmembers will be able to earn 160 XPs if they spend $25,000 on the card in anniversary year.

I’m very happy to see these changes to the card!

I find the Air France-KLM Flying Blue program to be super useful, which is why I have Platinum status in the program. It’s fantastic to see Flying Blue actually make it more compelling to use the card for spending.

If I can earn 160 XPs per year by spending $25,000 on the card, all while earning a minimum of 1.5x miles, I’d consider that to be a worthwhile opportunity. For context on XPs, that’s the metric by which you earn status with the Flying Blue program:

100 XPs gets you Silver status

You then need 180 additional XPs to earn Gold status

You then need 300 additional XPs to earn Platinum status

The clock resets as you work your way up the tiers. In other words, if you’re starting from scratch, you’d need a total of 580 XPs to earn Platinum status, but you’d have more than a year, since the tiers keep resetting. Meanwhile if you already have Platinum status, you only need 300 XPs to requalify for the status.

So by spending $25,000 on the card per year, that’ll get me over half way to Platinum status. Personally, I didn’t find it worthwhile to put spending on the card before, so I’m very happy to see this. I also find the annual fee on the card easy to justify, since the 5,000 miles go a long way to offsetting the $89 annual fee.

Kudos to Flying Blue on these changes. If I had any wish, it’s that it would be awesome if there were even more opportunities to earn XPs for spending on the card. The folks at Flying Blue are savvy and understand the US market really well, so you’d think they’d embrace credit card spending as much as possible.

Bottom line

The Air France-KLM credit card in the United States is going to see some updates. For one, it’ll go from being a Mastercard to a Visa, which is the most minor change, as I see it. On top of that, the card will earn 3x miles on dining, and it’ll also be possible to earn up to 160 XPs on the card per year, by spending $25,000.

When you consider that the annual fee is staying the same, I’d consider these to be entirely positive changes. At least for me, Flying Blue will accomplish its goal — I’ll be switching some spending to the card!

title: Nova Pangaea appoints new CEO - Bdaily
description:
Nova Pangaea Technologies, the Tees Valley-based company behind a novel technology to produce sustainable aviation fuel from waste biomass, has appointed cleantech veteran Stewart Stewart as its new chief executive.
Across his career, he has helped raise more than £150 million in equity and project capital for energy technologies.
Stewart said: “Nova Pangaea has developed a truly differentiated platform to convert biomass into sustainable fuels at scale.
“It’s a forward-looking business doing important work on low-carbon technologies, including projects with real carbon-capture benefits, while creating skilled jobs and investment locally.
“It has the infrastructure, skills, and industrial heritage needed to lead the next generation of cleaner industry, and companies like Nova Pangaea show exactly what that future can look like.
text:
Nova Pangaea Technologies, the Tees Valley-based company behind a novel technology to produce sustainable aviation fuel from waste biomass, has appointed cleantech veteran Stewart Stewart as its new chief executive.

Stewart brings more than 30 years’ experience commercialising breakthrough energy and low-carbon technologies and scaling venture-backed businesses in the UK and US. As chief executive, he will lead Nova Pangaea’s next phase of growth, including the development of its first commercial-scale production plant, as the company works to decarbonise aviation.

The company is backed by International Airlines Group and is currently working with British Airways and LanzaJet on Project Speedbird, a Government-supported collaboration to produce sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) in the UK.

Stewart joins from New York-based investment bank Javelin Capital, where he advised on green fuel opportunities.

Previously, he held executive leadership roles at cleantech companies BayoTech and Concord Blue Energy in the US and served as a senior advisor to London-based Ikigai Energy, supporting UK infrastructure owners on decarbonisation strategies.

Across his career, he has helped raise more than £150 million in equity and project capital for energy technologies.

Stewart said: “Nova Pangaea has developed a truly differentiated platform to convert biomass into sustainable fuels at scale.

“I’m excited to work with the team and our strategic partners to accelerate commercialisation, develop projects in the UK and globally, and build a world-class company, delivering both climate impact and long-term value.”

Nova Pangaea’s proprietary REFNOVA technology converts agricultural and wood residues, including wheat straw and wood chips, into bioethanol, which can then be processed into SAF.

The company operates a demonstration plant at its headquarters at Wilton International and plans to deploy its technology across four UK production plants as part of Project Speedbird, alongside international licensing opportunities.

To date, the company has raised more than £21 million from investors including IAG, PXN Ventures, Mercia Ventures and the Northern Powerhouse Investment Fund, alongside £7 million in grant funding.

Gerald Koch, chairman of the board, added: “It’s great to have Stewart with his experience, network and personal energy on board to deliver the next important milestones in the technology and the first commercial-scale plant.”

Anna Turley, MP for Redcar, added: “Nova Pangaea Technologies is something we can be genuinely proud of here in Redcar & Cleveland.

“It’s a forward-looking business doing important work on low-carbon technologies, including projects with real carbon-capture benefits, while creating skilled jobs and investment locally.

“Wilton is a hugely important site for our area and for the country.

“It has the infrastructure, skills, and industrial heritage needed to lead the next generation of cleaner industry, and companies like Nova Pangaea show exactly what that future can look like.

“I welcome the appointment of the new chief executive and wish them every success as the company moves into its next chapter.”

Decarbonizing Aviation: Discussions on Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) are critical for meeting India’s net-zero targets and ensuring the long-term sustainability of the sector.

text:
SDG 9: Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure | SDG 17: Partnerships for the Goals

Ministry of Civil Aviation

Minister of Civil Aviation Shri Rammohan Naidu has formally launched Wings India 2026, scheduled to take place from 28 to 31 January 2026 at Begumpet Airport, Hyderabad. Themed “Indian Aviation: Paving the Future – From Design to Deployment, Manufacturing to Maintenance, Inclusivity to Innovation and Safety to Sustainability,” the four-day global gathering will showcase India’s vision to become a premier hub for manufacturing and sustainable aviation solutions. The event serves as a critical convergence point for policymakers and industry leaders to deliberate on emerging trends like Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) and Advanced Air Mobility.

Key Event Highlights and Platforms

Global CEOs Forum: A high-level platform for industry leaders and investors to discuss collaborative pathways for the future of civil aviation.

Thematic Sessions: The international conference will feature 13 thematic sessions covering aircraft leasing, MRO (Maintenance, Repair, and Overhaul), air cargo, and women in aviation.

Innovation Challenge: A specially curated challenge for students and young professionals aimed at promoting industry-oriented problem-solving.

Aviation Job Fair: A dedicated initiative to connect skilled talent across the aviation ecosystem with industry leaders.

Spectacular Displays: Static aircraft displays and aerobatic shows by the Surya Kiran Aerobatic Team of the Indian Air Force.

International and Domestic Participation

Global Representation: Ministerial-level delegations and senior officials from more than 20 countries will participate to reinforce international cooperation.

State Showcases: Active participation from Indian states will highlight regional investment opportunities and aviation-led infrastructure growth.

Stakeholder Convergence: Participants include airlines, engine manufacturers, airport developers, and technology providers across the entire aviation value chain.

What is ‘Advanced Air Mobility (AAM)’ and why is it a focal point of Wings India 2026? It refers to an air transportation system that moves people and property by air using highly automated aircraft, such as electric Vertical Take-off and Landing (eVTOL) vehicles, typically in urban or short-range environments. Wings India 2026 identifies AAM as a focal point because it represents the next frontier of sustainable urban transportation, offering solutions to ground congestion while aligning with India’s broader goals for innovation and safety. By hosting dedicated sessions on AAM and drones, the event aims to position India as a leading adopter and manufacturer of these disruptive, zero-emission aviation technologies.

Policy Relevance

The event underscores India’s strategic push to localize the aviation value chain and lead global discourse on sustainable aviation practices.

Strategic Impact for India:

Scaling ‘Make in India’ in Aerospace: By focusing on “Design to Deployment,” the event seeks to attract global OEMs to establish manufacturing and MRO bases within India.

Decarbonizing Aviation: Discussions on Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) are critical for meeting India’s net-zero targets and ensuring the long-term sustainability of the sector.

Promoting Inclusivity: The dedicated “Women in Aviation” session highlights a policy priority to enhance gender diversity and representation in high-tech aerospace roles.

Enhancing Regional Connectivity: Showcasing state-led infrastructure development supports the government’s goal of making air travel affordable and accessible to Tier-II and Tier-III cities.

Relevant Question for Policy Stakeholders: How can the Ministry of Civil Aviation facilitate the creation of ‘Green Aviation Corridors’ that incentivize the early adoption of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) across domestic flight routes?

title: eBay Teams Up with FedEx, UPS, and DHL to Slash Carbon Footprint by 2045
description:
The company’s goals are clear: reduce its carbon footprint by 27.5% by 2030 and aim for a 90% reduction by 2045.
To achieve this, eBay is partnering with major carriers like DHL, FedEx, and UPS, all of which have committed to decarbonizing their operations.
DHL, FedEx, and UPS are already on the path, investing in electric vehicles and sustainable aviation fuels.
DHL and UPS have similar targets, aiming to incorporate sustainable aviation fuel in 30% of their air operations by 2035.
Implementing electric vehicles and investing in alternative fuels require significant resources, which not all companies are willing to allocate.
text:
eBay is stepping up its game in the fight against climate change with an ambitious new plan. The e-commerce giant, which connects 134 million sellers worldwide, has unveiled a roadmap to drastically cut its carbon emissions. Shipping, responsible for a whopping 84% of eBay’s total emissions, is at the heart of this challenge.

The company’s goals are clear: reduce its carbon footprint by 27.5% by 2030 and aim for a 90% reduction by 2045. To achieve this, eBay is partnering with major carriers like DHL, FedEx, and UPS, all of which have committed to decarbonizing their operations.

Shipping Giants to the Rescue

Without its own fleet or warehouses, eBay relies heavily on its partners to meet its climate goals. DHL, FedEx, and UPS are already on the path, investing in electric vehicles and sustainable aviation fuels. FedEx plans to transition to fully electric vehicles by 2030. DHL and UPS have similar targets, aiming to incorporate sustainable aviation fuel in 30% of their air operations by 2035.

These efforts mirror a broader trend among logistics companies to shrink their environmental footprint. However, the journey to a carbon-neutral future isn’t without hurdles. Climate-related challenges like floods and heatwaves could disrupt these strategies. eBay is urging its partners to collaborate closely to anticipate and mitigate these risks.

Challenges on the Green Road

While the plan is ambitious, it’s not without its critics. One major hurdle is the high cost of transitioning to greener technologies. Implementing electric vehicles and investing in alternative fuels require significant resources, which not all companies are willing to allocate.

Additionally, eBay must ensure its partners maintain their commitments and progress steadily. Unpredictable climate changes pose another potential risk, threatening supply chains and the ultimate goal of carbon neutrality.

As European regulations tighten and consumer expectations for sustainability rise, eBay must skillfully navigate this rapidly changing environment. Whether these initiatives will succeed and if the company will meet its ambitious targets remains to be seen.

title: The History of Commercial Flight: How Global Travel Took off - Airways Magazine
description:
Artemis Aerospace guides us through the different decades of air travel and how it has shaped modern-day living.
Innovation That Revolutionized Air Travel The introduction of the Douglas DC-3 in 1935 also had a big impact on the future of commercial flight.
Air Travel for the Masses Larger and more economical aircraft, such as the Boeing 747, had also made cheaper air travel possible.
Security Tightening in the 2000s The tragic events of 9/11 had a profound effect on air travel.
The years since the pandemic have reaffirmed a central truth: air travel adapts because it must.
text:
DALLAS — Flying has become the transport of choice for business travelers and holidaymakers across the globe and is now considered one of the fastest, most convenient, and safest forms of long-distance travel.

But how did commercial flights go from being exclusively for the wealthy to the mainstream and affordable option they are today? Artemis Aerospace guides us through the different decades of air travel and how it has shaped modern-day living.

The First Commercial Flight

The first ever passenger flight took off in May 1908 when Wilbur Wright carried Charles Furnas just 2000 feet across the beach at Kitty Hawk, North Carolina. Just one year later, the first airline in the world, the German airship company DELAG, was founded.

In 1914, the world’s first scheduled passenger service, an airboat piloted by Tony Jannus, set off from St. Petersburg, Florida, and landed at Tampa, around 17 miles away. The service only ran for four months, but it had unlocked the appetite of those keen to tap into the novelty of air transport.

A New Era of Aviation

However, it wasn’t until the 1920s that commercial flights carrying paying passengers started to become commonplace with the introduction of the multi-engine airplane, the Lawson C-2, which was specifically built to carry passengers.

During this time, more and more start-up airline carriers were being established, some of which are still in operation today. These include KLM in the Netherlands (1919), Colombia’s Avianca (1919), Qantas in Australia (1920), and Czech Airlines (1923).

Aircraft from this period would land frequently to refuel and fly at lower altitudes due to unpressurized cabins. This made traveling by plane noisy, cold, and expensive. Flying times were lengthy, and turbulence was frequent. Passengers regularly experienced air sickness, and many airlines hired nurses to reduce anxiety and tend to those affected.

In 1935, one of the world’s oldest airlines, Qantas, operated its first international passenger flight, traveling from Brisbane to Singapore. From there, British-owned Imperial Airways connected this flight to the UK. This was to set the wheels in motion for creating a regular travel route between Australia and the UK in the coming decades.

Despite flying being incredibly dangerous and extremely expensive during this period, it was still a fashionable way to travel for the rich. According to the Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum, the number of airline passengers grew from just 6,000 in 1930 to nearly half a million by 1934; the aviation industry was well on its way to becoming hugely important to the global economy.

Innovation That Revolutionized Air Travel

The introduction of the Douglas DC-3 in 1935 also had a big impact on the future of commercial flight. The propeller-driven airliner was a larger and much improved aircraft compared to its predecessors. Faster and more reliable, it could carry up to 32 passengers and had a cruising speed of 207 mph with a range of 1500 miles. This made it popular with well-established airlines, including Delta, TWA, American, and United, who soon added the aircraft to their fleets.

During the 1940s, the onset of WWII meant commercial aviation developments slowed considerably. However, by the end of the decade, the industry was heading towards a new era as Pan Am began operating its fleet of Boeing 307s, which featured the first-ever pressurized cabin.

This transformed air travel for passengers, allowing them to enjoy a comfortable experience at an altitude of 20,000 feet. Major airlines were now ramping up their advertising spending and offering travelers smooth journeys to far-flung destinations and business hubs, including Pan Am’s iconic New York-London route.

The Golden Age of Air Travel

The 1950s and 1960s heralded the age of jet engine aircraft, and with it came an upsurge in commercial flights, airline carriers, and international flying routes.

Commercial air travel was booming, and major airlines were fiercely competitive, offering passengers more and more inflight perks, including lavish silver-service meals and fine wines.

Pan Am was a front-runner in pioneering and marketing the very best air travel had to offer. It was the first airline to fly worldwide and introduced ground-breaking changes to the industry, such as adding jet aircraft to their fleets and utilizing computerized reservation systems.

In the 1960s, work began on creating the world’s first supersonic aircraft and what would eventually become an iconic symbol of commercial flight, the Concorde. Offering transatlantic flights in just 3.5 hours, the aircraft was a hit with business travelers and royalty alike. However, tickets were extremely expensive and only a privileged few could afford to travel via Concorde.

The Rise of the No-frills Airline

Seeing a gap in the market for making air travel more accessible to everyday people, British-owned Laker Airways, founded in 1966 by Freddie Laker, was one of the first airlines to start offering a budget alternative by adjusting its inflight offer.

Using the budget airline business model that is commonplace today, Laker was able to offer lower fares by reducing inflight services and luxuries, such as free meals. The airline also found innovative ways to reduce fuel consumption and engine wear by introducing the reduced thrust take-off technique and faster climbs to obtain the optimum flying altitude in as little time as possible. Sadly, the airline was a casualty of the 1980s recession and subsequently went bankrupt.

However, it paved the way for budget travel and opened a world of possibilities for millions more people to get the chance to travel by air.

Today, the world’s largest low-cost carrier is Southwest Airlines in the US. Synonymous with budget travel, the company’s low-cost domestic and short-haul offer has undoubtedly inspired many other well-known brands to tap into the no-frills market, including Ryanair and EasyJet.

Air Travel for the Masses

Larger and more economical aircraft, such as the Boeing 747, had also made cheaper air travel possible. Airlines were now able to carry more passengers than ever before, meaning ticket prices could be sold at a reduced rate. Holidaying abroad was no longer reserved for the rich.

This change in dynamics meant airlines now started to look for different ways to retain the luxurious service and long lunches that had been synonymous with the golden age of travel, without compromising on providing a budget alternative.

First-class cabins, sophisticated onboard bars, and exclusive-use airport lounges meant those who could afford to, could still travel in style.

During the 1980s and 1990s, the budget airlines Ryanair and EasyJet launched. Offering airfares for as little as £20, they changed the face of commercial flying and put pressure on traditional carriers to lower ticket prices.

Security Tightening in the 2000s

The tragic events of 9/11 had a profound effect on air travel. Security at airports was increased significantly and passengers without a ticket at US airports could no longer accompany friends and family through security to the gate.

Cockpit security was also heightened. Previously, it had been possible for passengers to visit the flight deck and speak to the pilots. However, after 2001, cockpit doors were locked with only the pilots controlling who could enter.

A New Era for Air Travel

According to the Bureau of Transportation Statistics, it took until 2004 for air passenger numbers to reach pre-9/11 levels and until 2007 to reach a record high.

During this period, low-cost carriers were experiencing increased demand as the popularity of booking websites surged, and, by 2009, figures from the tourism research company PhoCusWright reported that half of all travel-related bookings were being made online.

Passenger numbers continued to surge throughout the 2010s, and by the end of the decade, the volume of travelers using commercial airlines was at an all-time high.

The Post-pandemic Era: Flying into a New Age for Aviation

Prior to the pandemic, the IATA projected that global passenger numbers could reach 7.2 billion by 2035. Few, however, could have anticipated the scale of disruption that followed: worldwide fleet groundings, fractured supply chains, volatile border policies, and the most severe financial shock in aviation history.

By 2024, global passenger traffic had largely returned to, and in some regions surpassed, pre-pandemic levels, marking one of the fastest recoveries the industry has ever experienced. International long-haul demand rebounded strongly across the Atlantic and Pacific, while emerging markets in Asia, the Middle East, and Latin America reshaped global traffic flows. New hubs gained prominence, secondary cities secured nonstop intercontinental links, and airlines rethought network strategies with resilience, not just growth, in mind.

Yet recovery has not meant a return to the old normal. From 2023 through early 2026, aviation has operated under persistent structural constraints. Aircraft delivery delays, engine reliability issues, pilot shortages, and air traffic control bottlenecks have limited capacity just as demand surged. Airlines responded by extending fleet lifespans, accelerating cabin retrofits, and prioritizing yield over sheer scale — signaling a more disciplined era of growth.

The Promises to Come True

At the same time, sustainability moved from aspiration to operational reality. Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) production expanded, regulatory frameworks tightened in Europe and beyond, and airlines increasingly tied long-term strategies to fleet renewal conducive to cost and emissions reduction, and transparent environmental reporting. While the path to net-zero remains complex, aviation entered 2026 with clearer benchmarks and stronger alignment between policy, manufacturers, and operators than at any point before.

Technology and passenger expectations have also reshaped the experience of flying. AI-driven operations, biometric processing, next-generation premium cabins, and redesigned airport infrastructure reflect an industry focused on efficiency, comfort, and differentiation. Premium and long-haul leisure travel proved especially resilient, reinforcing aviation’s role not just as transport, but as a lifestyle and economic enabler.

As we move deeper into this new era, global aviation stands neither fragile nor complacent, but transformed. The years since the pandemic have reaffirmed a central truth: air travel adapts because it must. No matter the geopolitical, economic, or environmental challenges ahead, the impulse to connect across cities, continents, and cultures remains fundamental.

title: CBG production set to take off under Sumitomo–TruAlt pact - Manufacturing Today India
description:
Sumitomo Corporation has partnered with India’s largest ethanol producer to build a large compressed biomethane gas (CBG) business.
The collaboration with TruAlt Bioenergy Limited will see 16 CBG plants developed across India.
Strategic partnership to scale CBG in India On 11 November 2025, Sumitomo Corporation agreed to acquire a stake in TruAlt Gas Private Limited (TGPL), a subsidiary of TruAlt Bioenergy Limited, and enter into a strategic collaboration.
Sumitomo Corporation and TruAlt will also explore expanding bioethanol capacity and producing sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) from bioethanol.
Commenting on the collaboration, Sumitomo Corporation believes the project would strengthen its Energy Solutions Business and support its long-term goal of achieving carbon neutrality by 2050.
text:
Sumitomo Corporation has partnered with India’s largest ethanol producer to build a large compressed biomethane gas (CBG) business. The collaboration with TruAlt Bioenergy Limited will see 16 CBG plants developed across India. Could this waste-to-energy push reshape India’s clean fuel future?

Strategic partnership to scale CBG in India

On 11 November 2025, Sumitomo Corporation agreed to acquire a stake in TruAlt Gas Private Limited (TGPL), a subsidiary of TruAlt Bioenergy Limited, and enter into a strategic collaboration. Following the investment, TGPL will be renamed TruAlt Sumi Gas Private Limited (TSGPL).

TSGPL plans to build 16 compressed biomethane gas production facilities across India over the next three years, with operations starting in phases from 2026. Once fully operational, the plants are expected to produce around 320 tonnes of CBG per day, equivalent to the daily gas needs of nearly 800,000 Indian households. The gas will mainly be sold as automobile fuel to city gas distributors.

Also Read: BPCL mobilises industry for a cleaner energy choice

Supporting energy security and government targets

India, the world’s third-largest energy consumer, is pushing to improve energy self-sufficiency and reach energy independence by 2047. CBG plays a key role in this plan, as it is produced from agricultural and industrial waste such as sugarcane and ethanol residue.

The Indian government has mandated CBG blending in vehicle fuel and household city gas, targeting a 5 per cent blend by 2028. This policy has made rapid expansion of CBG production facilities a priority.

Expansion plans and future bioenergy initiatives

TSGPL will first construct four CBG plants in Karnataka and Maharashtra, major sugarcane-producing regions. Sumitomo Corporation and TruAlt will also explore expanding bioethanol capacity and producing sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) from bioethanol.

Commenting on the collaboration, Sumitomo Corporation believes the project would strengthen its Energy Solutions Business and support its long-term goal of achieving carbon neutrality by 2050.
